Name: Artichoke, globe
Description: Artichoke is a handsome herbaceous edible perennial with large gray spined leaves and purple thistle-like flowers in autumn. Native to the Mediterranean region, artichoke is tender and often best grown as an annual in colder hardiness zones. Bees and butterflies love the flowers of this plant.

Name: Asparagus
Description: Asparagus is one of the few truly perennial Vegetable/Fruits. It is a clump-forming herbaceous perennial native to the seacoast of Europe, Asia and North Africa. Mature asparagus is ferny in appearance. The much sought after luscious, asparagus spears are immature or unexpanded stems.

Name: Basil
Description: Companion to tomatoes. Dislikes rue intensely. Improves growth and flavor. Repels flies and mosquitoes

Name: Bean, bush
Description: Bush Beans are very prolific and can stand erect without support. They yield well and requires minimal work. Green bush beans were formerly called "string beans" because fiber developed along the seams of the pods.

Name: Bean, lima
Description: Sometimes called "butter beans" because of their starchy yet buttery texture, lima beans have a delicate flavor that complements a wide variety of dishes.

Name: Bean, pole
Description: Pole bean flavor is far better than even the best bush beans — they're sweeter and starchier. Pole beans have a longer harvest window and can be harvested upright — giving your back a break!

Name: Bee balm
Description: Bee Balm is a great companion for tomatoes. It improves growth and flavor.

Name: Beet
Description: Beets are wonderfully colorful root Vegetable/Fruits that originate from Europe, where they have been cultivated for hundreds of years. Usually grown as annuals, beets are actually biennials, which means they generate large roots and lush foliage in the first year and flower, set seed and die in the second.

Name: Borage
Description: Companion to tomatoes, squash, and strawberries. Deters tomato worms. Improves growth and flavor.

Name: Broccoli
Description: Broccoli (also known as Italian or sprouting broccoli) is typically grown as an annual, cool season Vegetable/Fruit. It is grown for its fleshy heads of flower buds, which are harvested and eaten before the flowers open.

Name: Brussels sprout
Description: The Brussels sprout is a cool season Vegetable/Fruit that is typically grown as an annual. It traces its ancestry to Brassica Oleracea, a fleshy-leaved, short-lived perennial from coastal areas of western and southern Europe.

Name: Cabbage
Description: Available in many shapes and colors, cabbage forms large, dense heads of thick, fleshy leaves. Typically grown as an annual, this cool season Vegetable/Fruit is a fleshy-leaved, short-lived perennial that originates from the coastal areas of western and southern Europe.

Name: Cabbage, Chinese
Description: There are many types of Chinese cabbage, but the type most associated with the term Chinese cabbage is also known as Napa cabbage. Napa cabbage is a large, tight-headed, fresh green that looks somewhat like a pale romaine lettuce. The flavor is sweeter and milder than traditional cabbage.

Name: Cantaloupe
Description: Fragrant and delicious, these warm season plants have been bred and revered by cultures worldwide and come in all shapes, sizes and colors. Muskmelons, cantaloupes, and “late melons” like honeydew and casaba,are all Cucumis Melo variants believed to have origins in Africa.

Name: Caraway
Description: Plant here and there. Loosens soil.

Name: Carrot
Description: The cultivated carrot is a hardy, herbaceous, biennial of European and Asian origin. Although carrots are biennial, they rarely get the chance to flower because their roots are harvested in the first season. If allowed to flower, it has large, pretty, lacy, white umbrella-shaped blooms that appear in summer.

Name: Catnip
Description: Plant in borders. Deters flea beetles.

Name: Cauliflower
Description: Cauliflower is an excellent choice for the cool-season Vegetable/Fruit garden. Cauliflower develops no side shoots, so bears only one crop. Plants do poorly in hot weather, becoming lanky and flowering rather than remaining in bud.

Name: Celery
Description: Grown for its yummy crisp fleshy leaf stems (petioles) and fragrant seeds, celery originates from Europe, northern Africa, India and Asia. It has been cultivated since ancient times and is a staple herb in many dishes across the world.

Name: Chamomile
Description: Companion to cabbage and onions. Improves growth and flavor.

Name: Chard, Swiss
Description: Swiss chard is usually grown as an annual, but it is a true biennial. Unlike its cousin the beet, chard is not grown for its fleshy roots but for its large leaves with fleshy edible stems that can be harvested all season.

Name: Chervil
Description: Companion to radishes. Improves growth and flavor.

Name: Chives
Description: Companion to carrots. Improves growth and flavor.

Name: Collard
Description: Collard is a cool-season Vegetable/Fruit that resembles a loose-leaved cabbage. Typically grown as an annual, this Vegetable/Fruit traces its ancestry to Brassica oleracea, a fleshy-leaved, short-lived perennial from coastal areas of western and southern Europe.

Name: Corn
Description: Corn is a warm season annual garden Vegetable/Fruit. The tall grassy plants will take off as soon as days and nights lose their chill. They develop tall stalks with long, thick arching green blades.

Name: Cucumber
Description: Asian in origin, cucumbers have been cultivated since ancient times. These frost-tender annual vines thrive in the warmth and sunshine of summer. They have large, broadly lobed leaves that are green and scratchy to the touch.

Name: Dead nettle
Description: Companion to potatoes. Deters potato bugs. Improves growth and flavor.

Name: Dill
Description: Companion to cabbage. Dislikes carrots. Improves the growth and health of cabbage.

Name: Eggplant
Description: Eggplant is an easy, warm-season Vegetable/Fruit that’s well worth the effort. Though perennial in its native Africa and Asia, most gardeners grow it as an annual Vegetable/Fruit crop. For best flavor and smaller seeds, pick the fruits just before they reach full size.

Name: Endive
Description: This leafy Vegetable/Fruit is surprisingly a member of the daisy family along with radicchio and chicory and easily grown in the home garden. Endive is grown as an annual and is low-growing usually forming rosettes, much like lettuce.

Name: Fennel
Description: Plant fennels away from your gardens! Most plants dislike its company.

Name: Flax
Description: Flax is a great companion to carrots and potatoes. Deters potato bugs and improves growth and flavor.

Name: Garlic
Description: This ancient crop that was first grown in present day Central Asia and India before it reached the ancient Egyptians through trade and they began cultivating it around 3200 BC. The ancient Hebrews, Greeks and Romans also valued garlic for food and as a medicinal curative.

Name: Henbit
Description: Henbit plants acts as a general insect repellent.

Name: Horseradish
Description: Horseradish is a widely-adapted, hardy perennial producing roots that are ground or finely shredded to make wonderfully hot and sweet sauces and condiments. Roots should be divided and replanted every 2 years to prevent them from becoming woody.

Name: Hyssop
Description: Hyssop deters cabbage moths and is a great companion to cabbage and grapes. But be sure to plant hyssops away from radishes.

Name: Kale
Description: Typically grown as an annual, kale is a cool season Vegetable/Fruit tracing its ancestry to Brassica oleracea, a fleshy-leaved, short-lived perennial from coastal areas of western and southern Europe

Name: Kohlrabi
Description: Kohlrabi is one of many crops that descend from Brassica Oleracea, an annual or short-lived perennial from Western Europe. The name “kohlrabi” roughly translates to "cabbage-turnip" in German. Be sure to harvest immediately once it reaches maturity, otherwise it may become woody.

Name: Lamb's quarters
Description: This edible weed should be allowed to grow in moderate amounts in the garden, especially in corn.

Name: Leek
Description: Leeks have a delicate, sweet oniony flavor that cannot be matched, and though they take a bit more work to cultivate, they are well worth growing. Unlike onions, their leaf bases are eaten as well as the bulbs. They are technically short-lived perennials but are grown as annuals.

Name: Lemon balm
Description: Sprinkle throughout the garden.

Name: Lettuce, head
Description: Loosehead or butterhead lettuce is an annual garden green grown for its smooth, thin, buttery leaves and looser heads. When temperatures warm up, the whole leafy clump elongates and grows upwards. At this stage they are no longer good eating.

Name: Lettuce, leaf
Description: Loose leaf lettuce is one of the simplest lettuces to grow in home gardens and the type grown by most home gardeners. You just plant it, water it, harvest it and eat it! Loose leaf lettuce varieties are those lettuces that do not form a compact head. Their flavor tends to be mild and sweet.

Name: Lovage
Description: Improves flavor and health of surrounding plants when planted here and there.

Name: Marigold
Description: Marigolds are the workhorse of the pest deterrents. Plant throughout the garden to discourage Mexican bean beetles, nematodes, and other insects.

Name: Marjoram
Description: Plant marjorams here and there in the garden and use to improve flavor.

Name: Mint
Description: Mint is a good companion to cabbage and tomatoes. It improves their health and flavor and deters white cabbage moths.

Name: Mole plant
Description: This plant can help deter moles and mice.

Name: Mustard
Description: A pungently flavored green, mustard is a fast growing, cool season annual or biennial that originates from Asia but has been introduced as a weed in many other parts of the world. Its greens add zest to salads and stir-fries and pungent seeds are used to make brown mustard.

Name: Nasturtium
Description: Nasturtium is a good companion to radishes, cabbage, and gourds and can be plant under fruit trees. They deter aphids, squash bugs, and striped pumpkin beetles while Improving growth and flavor.

Name: Okra
Description: Okra is in the same family as hollyhocks and hibiscus. This tropical annual Vegetable/Fruit originates from Africa.

Name: Onion
Description: The garden onion is a biennial or perennial widely grown as a root Vegetable/Fruit.

Name: Parsley
Description: Whether flat or curly-leaved, the leaves of parsley impart a fresh, green taste to food that helps clean the palate. This popular plant originates from southern Europe. It forms neat clumps of leaves that can be harvested throughout the growing season.

Name: Parsnip
Description: This extremely cold-hardy biennial is native to Europe and West Asia. The long, pale yellow, typically carrot-shaped taproot matures in fall from a spring sowing, and can be harvested as long as the ground remains workable. Its starchy flesh sweetens with fall frosts.

Name: Peas
Description: Peas have been cultivated for their edible seeds and pods for thousands of years. Their area of origin is thought to be the eastern Mediterranean region, including Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Syria, where wild pea plants still exist.

Name: Pepper
Description: The long, broad cultivation history of the pepper best explains why its fruits come in a myriad of forms tastes and colors. Native to tropical America, these annuals have been grown and selected by Native Americans since pre-history times.

Name: Peppermint
Description: Peppermint is a good companion to cabbages. It repels white cabbage butterflies.

Name: Petunia
Description: Petunia is a good companion to beans.

Name: Pigweed
Description: Pigweed is one of the best weeds for pumping nutrients from the subsoil. It is good for potatoes, onions, and corn. Be sure to keep weeds thinned.

Name: Pot marigold
Description: Pot marigold is a good companion to tomatoes, and be sure to plant elsewhere in the garden, too. It deters asparagus beetles, tomato worms, and general garden pests.

Name: Potato
Description: Potatoes are tender perennials widely cultivated as seasonal annual crops. The starchy potato tubers develop from underground stems. The small, shallow, pinkish eyes on each tuber are leaf buds that can sprout to form new plants. All green parts of a potato plant are poisonous!

Name: Pumpkin
Description: Pumpkin is a warm-season Vegetable/Fruit and can be grown in most of the United States.  It is considered a squash but is not always used for consumption as it has a stringier texture than other squash varieties.  However, pumpkin can certainly be enjoyed in many dishes including pies, breads, and soups.

Name: Purslane
Description: Purslanes deter asparagus beetles, tomato worms, and general garden pests.

Name: Radish
Description: Radishes are easy to grow and they grow fast. Like many crops in the cabbage family, these natives of Europe and Asia grow best in mild, cool weather, so they are best grown in spring and fall where summers are hot.

Name: Rhubarb
Description: Be patient with rhubarb. You will not harvest any of the Vegetable/Fruit until the second year and then only in small amounts.  The third year will give a much larger yield. Remember that only the leaf stalks are edible. All other parts of the plant are highly toxic!

Name: Rosemary
Description: Rosemary is a good companion to cabbage, beans, carrots, and sage. It deters cabbage moths, bean bettles and carrot flies.

Name: Rue
Description: Be sure to keep this plant far away from basil. Rues make good companion to roses and raspberries. It deters Japanese beetles.

Name: Rutabaga
Description: Rutabagas are created by a natural cross between cabbage and turnip. Compared to turnips, rutabagas grow larger (thanks to their cabbage heritage) and require a few weeks longer to mature.

Name: Sage
Description: Plant with rosemary, cabbage, and carrots. Be sure to keep away from cucumbers. Safe deters cabbage moth, and carrot flies.

Name: Southernwood
Description: Plant here and there in garden, or plant it as a companion to cabbage. It improves growth and flavor and deters cabbage moths.

Name: Sow thistle
Description: This weed in moderate amounts can help tomatoes, onions, and corn.

Name: Spinach
Description: The lovely dark green leaves of spinach are delicious cooked or raw and high in nutritional value. This cold hardy annual herb is a cool season crop that will quickly flower and die once temperatures heat up.

Name: Squash, summer
Description: The Summer Squash is a  warm season annual vine. They are New World plants grown widely by many cultures throughout the world and appear in a fantastic array of colors, shapes and sizes.

Name: Squash, winter
Description: Originating from South America, winter squash have been cultivated since ancient times by Native American peoples, and are prized today for both their culinary and decorative qualities. Most mature late in the season, and come in a variety of interesting shapes and festive colors.

Name: Summer savory
Description: Plant with beans and onions to improve growth and flavor. Summer savory deters bean beetles.

Name: Sweet Potato
Description: Sweet potato is a tender, warm-weather Vegetable/Fruit that requires a long frost-free growing season to mature large, useful roots. Sweet potato is native to Central and South America.

Name: Tansy
Description: Tansy is such an aggressive reseeder in some climates that it is listed as a noxious weed. Growing tansy is prohibited in Colorado, Minnesota, Montana, Wyoming, and parts of the state of Washington, as well as the Alberta and British Columbia provinces in Canada.

Name: Tarragon
Description: Tarragon is good addition throughout the garden.

Name: Thyme
Description: Plant thyme here and there in the garden. They deter cabbage worms.

Name: Tomato
Description: The garden tomato is a short-lived tender perennial vine that is grown as an annual crop. Its compound leaves are medium green, hairy and have a strong fragrance. Mature vines produce star-shaped yellow flowers in clusters along the branches. Most modern types are self-fertile.

Name: Turnip
Description: Turnip comes as annual or biennial. It is one of numerous leafy Vegetable/Fruits belonging to Brassica Rapa.

Name: Valerian
Sun Exposure: Full Sun, Partial Sun, Partial Shade
Description: Valerian is a good addition throughout the garden.

Name: Watermelon
Description: Watermelon is a tender annual vine that needs a long warm growing season to produce its famous fruits. The vines become quite large and cling using tendrils but are best left grounded. The sheer weight and size of melons precludes fence or trellis training.

Name: Wormwood
Description: Plant wormwood as a border. It keeps animals from the garden.

Name: Yarrow
Description: Plant yarrows along borders, paths, and near aromatic herbs. Yarrow enhances essential oil production.
